div.p: This edition is not printed for circulation in the United States—the American copy is published by Mr. Wemyss, 575, Broadway, New York, and permission to perform it must be obtained of the author, Mr. A. Daly. To both these gentlemen, I offer a sincere expression of regret that I have at length allowed myself to follow the disreputable example of some New York and Boston publishers, and appropriate property to which I have, certainly, no moral right. I have for years wholly repudiated the practice of pilfering from Americans, and should never, at any time, have assumed what I consider to be a degrading, if not a dishonest position, had I not been the victim of hundreds of instances of similar delinquency from the other side of the Atlantic. The most annoying and injurious instance of this is the case of “The Amateur’s Guide,” which, in design and treatment, was altogether original. I knew such a publication was really wanted, and it occupied all the time I could spare for months in arrangement, compilation, and new matter. I anticipated that it would be stolen, but I did not expect that the gentleman who terms himself my agent in New York should hurriedly thrust a mutilated version of it on the American Public with a studious withholding of my name from the book altogether, and that my own Preface should be copied, and signed by Tony Denier as the author of the book. This is doubtless an assumed name, for no real personage would have placed himself in so shabby a light, and would have so deliberately gibbeted himself as he has done, by the shameless assertion that he is the Author or compiler of a work of which he did not write or compile a line, Sympathising with the honest movement now agitating the public attention in America for a reciprocal protection — of literary property—I have taken this step to aid it, and deliberately — assert that had Mr. Daly possessed the right to introduce this drama into England and her Colonies—its merit is such that he might have hoped to derive an important pecuniary result therefrom for years—all which is sacrificed by the disinclination of the American Government to believe in the genius and inventive power of its own citizens,

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: —Parlour at the Courtlands, deep window at back showing snowy exterior—street lamp lighted—time, night—the place elegantly furnished, chandelier, &c.
Ray Trafford is discovered lounging on tete-a-tete C., Pearl is at L. d. taking leave of Demilt, Windel, Mrs. Van Dam, and Sue Earlie, who are all dressed and muffled to go out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Good night! Of course we'll see you on Tuesday.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: To be sure you will.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Never spent a jollier hour. Good-night, Ray.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Good night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: You won't forget the sociable on Tuesday, Ray?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: O, I won't forget.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good night—good night.

div.stage: (exeunt De Milt, Windel, Mrs. Van Dam, and Miss Earlie, L. door.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Good night. (coming forward) Oh, dear, now they're gone and the holiday's gone with them. (goes to window) There they go. (laughter without) Ray, do come and look at the Van Dam's new sleigh. How they have come out.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes, it's the gayest thing in the park.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I wonder where they got the money! I thought you said Van Dam had failed!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Well, yes. He failed to pay, but he continues to spend.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Good-night! (response from without as sleigh bells jingle “good night) I wish I was in there with you. It's delightful for a sleigh ride, if it wasn't New Year's. O! there's Demilt over. (laughter outside, cracking of whips, Ray saunters up to window, sleigh bells jingle, sleigh music heard to die away, Ray and Pearl wave their handkerchiefs, Ray comes down and sits C.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Isn't it a frightful thing to be shut up here on such a beautiful night, and New Year's of all others. Pshaw, we've had nothing but mopes all day. O, dear, I hate mourning, though it does become me, and I hate everything but fun, larks, and dancing. (comes down)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Where in the world is Laura?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O, do forget her for a second, can't you? She'll be here presently. You're not in the house a minute but it's “Where's Laura?” “Why don't Laura come?”

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Well, if anybody in the world could make me forget her it would be you. But if you had a lover, wouldn't you like him to be as constant as that?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: That's quite another thing.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: But this doesn't answer my question. Where is she?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I sent for her as soon as I saw you coming. She has hardly been down here a moment all this evening. O, dear! Now don't you think I'm a victim, to be cooped up in this way instead of receiving calls as we used to?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You forget that your mother died only last summer. (rising)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: No, I don't forget. Pshaw, you're just like Laura. She's only my cousin, and yet she keeps always saying “Poor aunt Mary. Let us not forget how she would have sorrowed for us.”

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Well, don't you know she would, too?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I don't know anything about it. I was always at boarding school, and she only saw me once a year. Laura was always at home, and it's very different. But don't let's talk about it. To die—ugh! I don't want to die till I don't want to live—and that'll not be for a million of years. Come, tell me, where have you been to-day? How many calls did you make? (sitting in tete-a-tete)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: About sixty.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: That's all? You're lazy. Demilt and Windel made a hundred and thirty, an they say that's nothing. Won't you have a cup of coffee?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Ain't you hungry?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: No—you torment.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O, dear! I suppose it's because you're going to be married shortly to Laura. If there's one time that a man's stupid to his friends, it's when he's going to be married shortly. Tell me whom you saw. (Ray has sauntered off L. and is looking over cards on table) Where are you? Oh, you needn't be so impatient to see her. Do be agreeable. Sit here and tell me something funny, or I shall drop down and fall asleep.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You witch! Why didn't I fall in love with you?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I don't know—why didn't you?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You never keep me waiting. (listening off R.) Ah! that's her step. No.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Do sit down.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: This calling's a great bore, but as you and Laura insisted I should go through it I did. First I—(jumping up) I knew it was she. (goes to door R., meets Laura who enters) How you did keep me waiting. (kisses both her hands)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And you, sir, we have been looking for you since eight o'clock.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: O, I was fulfilling your orders. I've been engaged in the business of calling from ten o'clock in the morning till now (looks at watch) ten at night.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, you can make this your last one, for you have leave to spend a nice long hour chatting here before you go. Won't you have some supper? (goes to bell, on table L. 2 E.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I don't care if I do, I'm rather famished.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Well, I declare! Did Laura bring your appetite with her? (Laura rings)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I don't know how it is, but she brings me a relish for everything in life, I believe. Laura, I think if I were to lose you I'd mope to death and starve to death.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, that's as much to say I'm a sort of life pill.

div.stage: Enter Martin, door L.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Supper. (exit)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You may joke about it, but it's so. You take the lounge. (Laura and Pearl sit on tete-a-tete)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: You don't want me to go away, do you? (putting her head on Laura's shoulder)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Certainly not. What an idea!

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I'm sure you'll have time enough to be alone when you are married. And I do so want to talk and be talked to.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, Ray shall talk to you.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: He was just going to tell me about his calls to-day.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: That's exactly what we want to hear about. Did you call on every one we told you to?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Every one. There was Miss—

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Did you go to Henrietta Liston's first?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes, and wasn't she dressed! Speaking of dress, are you going to have your new pink for the sociable Tuesday?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, Pearl, and I will do credit to the occasion, as it is our first for a year.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And our last.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Our last!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura's and mine. For when we are married, you know, we shall be tabooed—where maids and bachelors only are permitted.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O bless me! (rising) How do you do, Mrs. Trafford?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I wish you hadn't said that, Pearl. You know the old proverb, “Call a maid by a married name.”

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Nonsense! (putting his arm about Laura's waist) It's only a few days to wait, and we'll live long enough, you know. For nothing but death shall separate us.

div.stage: Martin appears at door L.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O, here's supper.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Beg pardon, Miss.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: There's a person below, miss, who says he's been sent with a bouquet for you, miss, and must deliver it in person.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: For me? Whose servant is it?

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: I don't know, miss, he looks like one of those soldier messengers, red cap and all that.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Show him up here. (exit Martin L 2 E.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: How romantic. So late at night. It's a rival in disguise, Ray.

div.stage: Re-enter Martin showing in Snorkey with an air of disdain, Snorkey has a large bouquet in his left hand, and his hat is under the stump of his right arm, which is cut off.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You wished to see me.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Are you Miss Laura Courtland?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Then I was told to give you this.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.stage: (taking it from Ray who has crossed L. C. and received it from Snorkey)
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Now, that's what I don't know myself. You see I was down by the steps of the Fifth Avenue Hotel taking a light supper off a small toothpick, when a big chap dressed in black came by, and says he, “Hallo, come with me if you want to earn a quarter.” That (confidentially to all) being my very frame of mind, I went up one street and down another till we came here. “Just you take this up there,” says he, “and ask for Miss Laura Courtland, and give it to her and no one else.”

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: It is some folly of our late visitors.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: I'm one of the soldier messengers, miss. A South Carolina gentleman took such a fancy to me at Fredericksburg? Wouldn't have no denial—cut off my arm to remember me by; he was very fond of me. I wasn't any use to Uncle Sam then, so I came home, put a red band round my blue cap, and with my empty sleeve, as a character from my last place, set up for light porter and general messenger. All orders executed with neatness and dispatch.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Poor fellow! (to Servant) Martin, be sure and give him a glass of wine before he goes.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: I'm much obliged, miss, but I don't think it would be good for me on an empty stomach after fasting all day.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, Martin shall find you some supper, too.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p:
Is this Martin? What a nice young man! Mayn't he have a drop of something, too? He must have
caught cold letting me in, he has got such a dreadful stiffness in the back of his neck. (exit Martin, door L.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Call on me at this place to-morrow, and you shan't regret it.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: All right, cap'n. I havn't forgot the army regulations about punctuality and promotion. Ladies, if ever either of you should want a light porter think of Joe Snorkey—wages no objection. (exit L.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.stage: (c., who has been examining the bouquet)
sp.p: O, Laura, only look, here's a billet-doux.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Nonsense, crazy head, who would dare? (takes bouquet) A letter! (takes a paper from bouquet)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: A letter?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I am crazy—am I?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: “For Miss Laura Courtland. Confidential.”

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ha, Ha! From some goose who has made one call too many to-day. Read it, Ray. (offering letter)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: “Dear Laura,—” (refusing the letter and going to Pearl)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.stage: (looks at it a moment, when the whole expression of face changes, then reads slowly and deliberately, Ray down R. C. with Pearl)
sp.p: “I respectfully beg you to grant me the favour of an interview to-night. I have waited until your company retired. I am waiting across the street now.”

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: A tall man in black is just walking away.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: “If you will have the door opened as soon as you get this I will step over; if you don't, I will ring; under all circumstances I will get in. There is no need to sign my name; you will remember me as the strange man whom you once saw talking with your mother in the parlour, and who frightened you so much.” What can be the meaning of this? Pearl—no. (goes to bell on table L. and rings)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, you—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ask me nothing. I will tell you by-and-bye.

div.stage: Enter Martin, L.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: Miss—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Admit no one till you bring me the name.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: I was about to tell you, miss, that a strange man has forced himself in at the door and asks to see you, but will give no name.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Kick the rascal out. (X's to L.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Oh, don't let him come here.

sp.speaker: Martin.
sp.p: He's a very strange-looking person, miss.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I'll find out what this means. (is going to door L. when Byke appears at it smiling and bowing)

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: I'll spare you the trouble if you'll hear me a minute.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Who are you, fellow?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Don't, I beg you. Don't speak so crossly, I might answer back, then you'd kick me out, and you'd never forgive yourself for it as long as I lived.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Your business? Come, speak quickly and begone.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Business, on this happy day! I came for pleasure—to see Miss Courtland, my little pupil—grown so—only think, sir, I knew her when she was only a little child, I taught her music—she was so musical—and so beautiful—I adored her, and her mother told me I needn't come again. But I did, and her mother was glad to see me, wasn't she, little pupil? (to Laura, who is pale with terror, leaning on Pearl, R., Ray C., Byke L.) and begged me to stay—but I said no—I'd call occasionally—to see my dear little pupil and to receive any trifling contribution her mother might give me. Won't you shake hands, little pupil? (advances suddenly, when Ray grasps him by the collar, Byke glares at him a moment, then quickly, as before) Don't, please, don't, the stuff is old and I've no other.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: The fellow's drunk. Leave the house.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: What, after sending that touching bouquet?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: It was you, then? I knew it.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: You see she knows me. Ah, memory, how it blooms again where the plough of time has passed.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Leave this house at once.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Not until I have spoken to you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You miserable rascal.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Don't, pray don't. I weigh a hundred and ninety-eight pounds, and if you attempt to throw me about you'll strain yourself.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Go, to-morrow in the morning I will see you.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Thanks. I thank you, miss, for your forbearance. (to Ray) I am also obliged to you, sir, for not throwing me out at the window. I am indeed. I wish you good-night and many happy returns of the day. (bows and turns to go, then familiarly to servant) Many calls to-day, John? (exit L.)

div.stage: Ray runs to Laura, who is pale and agitated.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: See that he goes (exit Ray, L. Laura, taking both of Pearl's hands in her own) Pearl, he must know everything.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O, dear, this is dreadful. I do hate scenes.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: He must know everything, I tell you; and you must relate all. He will question, he will ponder—leave him nothing to ask.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: If you wish it, but—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I desire it; speak of me as you will, hut tell him the truth.

div.stage: Enter Ray, hastily, L.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Stay with her, don't follow me. (exit Laura, R.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Pearl, what does this mean?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O, it's only a little cloud that I want to clear up for you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Cloud? How? Where?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Don't I tell you I am going to tell you. Sit down here by me. (she sinks into tete-a-tete, C.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: He said he knew her. And she gave him an interview for to-morrow. That drunken wretch—

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Do sit down. I can never speak while you are walking about so. (gets up, brings him to a chair R. C. and makes him sit) Sit by me, won't you, for I've got something strange to tell you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You serious? I'd as soon expect to see the lightning tamed. Well, I listen.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: I have something to say to you, Ray, which you must settle with your own heart. You love Laura, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Pearl, I do more, I adore her. I adore the very air that she breathes. I will never be happy without her, I can swear that.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Laura is twenty now. How do you think she looked when I first saw her?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Were you at home when she first came into this earthly sphere?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Well then I suppose she looked very small and very pink.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: She was covered with rags, barefooted, unkempt, crying, and six years old.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: One night father and mother were going to the opera. When they were crossing Broadway, the usual crowd of children accosted them for alms. As mother felt in her pocket for some change, her fingers touched a cold and trembling hand which had clutched her purse.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: A pickpocket! Well?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: This hand my mother grasped in her own, and so tightly that a small, feeble voice uttered an exclamation of pain. Mother looked down, and there beside her was a little ragged girl.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: The thief.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Yes, but a thief hardly six years old, with a face like an angel's. “Stop!” said my mother, “what are you doing?” “Trying to steal,” said the child. “Don't you know that it's wicked to do so?” asked my father. “No,” said the girl, “but it's dreadful to be hungry.” “Who told you to steal?” asked my mother. “She—there!” said the child, pointing to a squalid woman in a doorway opposite, who fled suddenly down the street. “That is Old Judas,” said the girl.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Old Judas! What a name. But how does this story interest us?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: This child was Laura. My father was about to let her go unharmed, but my mother said, “No, it is not enough. We have a duty to perform, even to her,” and acting on a sudden impulse, took her to our home. On being questioned there, the child seemed to have no recollection save of misery and blows. My mother persuaded father, and the girl was sent to a country clergyman's for instruction, and there she remained for several years.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Pearl, you are joking with me.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: In beauty, and accomplishments, and dignity Laura, as mother named her, exceeded every girl of her age. In gratitude she was all that father could have wished. She was introduced, as you know, into society as my cousin, and no one dreams of her origin.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura an outcast—a thief!

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: No, that is what she might have been.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And this man—to-night?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: All I know about him is, that four years ago this man came with a cruel-looking woman, to see mother. There was a fearful scene between them, for Laura and I sat trembling on the stairs and overheard some awful words. At last they went away, the man putting money into his pocket as he left.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: But who were they?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Laura never told me, and mother would not. But, of course, they must have been Laura's father and mother. (Ray sinks on chair as if overcome)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Mother made me promise never to tell anybody this, and you would have known nothing had not Laura made me speak. You see, she would not conceal anything from you. (going to him) Ray, why don't you speak—shall I go after Laura? Shall I tell her to come to you? Why don't you answer? (going) I'll go and tell her you want to see her. (pausing as she goes R.) I'm going to send her to you, Ray. (goes off R. still looking back at him)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: What a frightful story. Laura Courtland a thief. A drunken wretch who knows her history, and a squalid beggar woman who can claim her at any moment as their child. And I was about to marry her. Yes, and I love her. But what would my mother think? My friends? Society? No—no—no—I cannot think of it. I will write her—I will tell her—pshaw! she knows, of course, that I cannot wed her now. (goes to the table L. U. E.) Here is paper. (sits) What am I about to do? What will be said of me? But I owe a duty to myself—to society—I must perform it. (writes) “Laura, I have heard all from your sister." What have I said crosses out last word)" from Pearl. You know that I love you, but my mother will demand of me a wife who will not blush to own her kindred, and who is not the daughter of obscurity and crime.” It is just—it is I who have been deceived. (folds letter and addresses it) I will leave it for her. (puts on light overcoat which hangs on chair at back) I must go before she returns. Her step—too late! (crams the letter into pocket of overcoat)

div.stage: Laura enters, R.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ray.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Miss—Miss Courtland. (Laura looks at him a moment, smiles, and then X's C. without further noticing him, and sits down on tete-a-tete) What have I said? What ought I to have said? (he takes a step towards her—she rises, without looking at him, goes to window, looks out, then looks over books on table R.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura—I—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Pshaw, where is my book?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: What book do you want, Laura?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Oh (pause) I've been a fool. How lovely she looks. (he follows her mechanically to table, L.) Can I find it for you?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Don't trouble yourself, I beg.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.stage: (coming forward and leaning over her seat)
sp.p: Laura.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Look at me.

div.stage: (Laura turns round and looks full at him.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: No, no, not that way—as you used to. You act as if I were a stranger.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: They are only strangers who call me Miss Courtland. (resumes reading)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Forgive me, I beg you to forgive me. (coming round and sitting beside her) I was mad—it was so sudden—this miserable story—but I don't care what they say. O, do listen to me. I thought you hated reading.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I often wish that I were ugly, wretched, and repulsive, like the heroine in this story. (seats herself)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Because then I could tell who really loved me.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And don't you know?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Well, I know.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Do tell me then, please.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: He has told you so himself a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: How happy must those women be who are poor, and friendless, and plain, when some true heart comes and says “I wish to marry you!”

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, you act very strangely to-night.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Will you put this book away?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: There, Laura. (seats himself beside her)

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: There's Pearl calling me.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, why don't you let me speak to you?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: About what?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: About my love.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: For whom? Not me. This is only marriage and giving in marriage. I hate the very word.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You did not think so once.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I wish I had. I am frightened now; I begin to understand myself better.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And I am frightened because I understand you less.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Do not try to; good night. (up R. C., stops by door as she is going out) Good night Mr. Trafford.

div.stage: (exit Laura, laughing R. 2 E.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I've been an ass. No, I wrong that noble animal. The ass recognised the angel, and I, like Balaam, was blind. But I see now. After all, what have I to fear? (takes letter from pocket) No one knows of this. (puts it in his pocket again) Let things go on, we'll be married, go straight to Europe, and live there ten years. That's the way we'll fix it. (exit Ray L. 2 E.,—scene closes in.)

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: —(1st grooves)—the gentlemen's coat-room at Delmonico's—opening C., for hat and coat. Chairs L. Pier-glass on flat.
Enter Windel and Demilt muffled, and with umbrellas, L. 2 E., they proceed to disrobe.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Phew! wet as the deuce, and cold too. There'll be nobody here.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: It's an awful night. The rooms are almost empty.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Sam! Where the dickens is that darkey?

div.stage: Enter Sam R., fetching in a chair, and boot-black, box and brush.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Here sah.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Hurry up with my boots. Who's here?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Berry few gemman, sah; only lebben overcoats and ten overshoes. Dem overshoes is spilin the polishin business.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Look out and don't give me any knocks.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.stage: (handing in his coat at window and getting check for it)
sp.p: I wonder if the Courtland girls have come yet.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: What did Laura Courtland ever see in Trafford to fall in love with? The Van Dam party is my fancy.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: She's ten years older than you, and has a husband.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p:
Yes, a fine old banker, on whom she can draw for
everything but attention and affection. She has to get that by her own business tact.

div.stage: (Other parties enter, L. 2. E., exchange good-nights, and deposit their coats; some go out at once, some arrange themselves at glass.)

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That'll do, Sam, take my coat.

div.stage: Enter Ray Trafford, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: Hallo! Trafford, this is a night, ain't it? Have the Courtlands come?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Not with me. Here, Sam, take my coat. (his coat is pulled off by Sam, and four letters drop out) Stupid!

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Save the pieces. Mind the love letters.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Look out well next time. There's that cursed letter I was going to send to Laura. Confound it, I must destroy it when I go home. (puts letter back in overcoat pocket—gets his boots touched up.)

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: I say, Trafford, what'll you take, and let a fellow read those? Windel, I guess if the girls could get into the cloak-room, it would be better than the dead-letter office. What a time they'd have! Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Wind.
sp.p: What's the use of hurrying? There is no life in the party till Laura Courtland comes. By Jove, Trafford! you're in luck. She's the prettiest girl in New York.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And the best? (march music heard.)

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: There's the march music, let's go. (gets a final brush as they all go off, R. 1 E.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Come along. (exeunt R. 1 E.)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.stage: (picking up a letter dropped from Ray's pocket)
sp.p: Dere's anoder of dem billy dooses; wonder if it am Mist' Trafford's. Eh, golly! musn't mix dem gentlemen's letters,—musn't mix 'em nohow,—or nobody or nuffing wouldn't be able to stop lighting in dis city for de nex month. (exit, carrying a chair &c., L. 1 E.)

div.head: SCENE THIRD.
div.stage: —The blue room at Delmonico's. Waltz music as the scene opens. Waltzers in motion—Pearl is dancing with Mrs. Van Dam.
Enter Ray Trafford, Demilt, and Windel, R.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: There Ray. I've had enough; I want to speak with him. (bursts away from Mrs. Van Dam, runs up to Trafford. Demilt goes up to Mrs. Van Dam.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: You lazy fellow, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: You're not tired, are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: I feel as fresh as a daisy.

sp.speaker: Demilt.
sp.p: Have a waltz with me. (waltz music, piano, as they dance, Windel goes to Miss Earlie.)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Where's Laura?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: She wasn't ready, and I was dying to come. Been fixed since eight o'clock; so I came with Miss Earlie. So you made it up with Laura?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes. Don't say anything more about the horrid subject. We've made it all up. But what on earth keeps her to-night? It's eleven already. (looking at watch) Confound it, I tremble every moment she's out of my sight. I fear that terrible man and his secret.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Trafford, you look very uneasy, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Oh, nothing. I think I ought to go for Laura. I will, too. (servant passes at back) Here! go upstairs for my overcoat. (gives the man a card, and he goes out.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Nonsense! She'll be here in good time. You shan't leave us. Hold him, Pearl. We want a nine-pin quadrille; we havn't half enough gentlemen. Come, be jolly about it. You lovers are always afraid someone will carry your girls away.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I? I'm not afraid.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Come, come! I never saw such a restless fellow.

div.stage: Enter Servant C., with coat.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here's your coat, sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Give it to me. I'm determined you shan't go. (takes coat carelessly) I'll make you a promise—if Laura isn't here in fifteen minutes, you shall have your coat, and may go for her.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Well, I suppose I'll have to wait.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: There, take him off, Pearl. (Ray goes off with Pearl R. U. E.—to Servant) Here, take this back. (flings coat to Servant, as she does so letters drop from it) Well, there! (Miss Earlie and another lady run forward and pick up letters) Love letters, of course! (smelling them) Perfumed to suffocation.

sp.speaker: Miss E.
sp.p: Here's one for Laura, its unsealed and not delivered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: A fair prize, let's see it. (Music—takes and opens it, puts on eye-glasses and reads) “Laura,” well, come, that's cool for a lover, “I have heard, all from”—something scratched out—ah!

div.p: “your sister, Pearl—your obscure origin—terrible family connexions—the secret of the tie which binds you to a drunken wretch—my mother, society—will demand of me a wife who will not blush to own her kindred—or start at the name of outcast and thief.—Signed, Ray Trafford.” (all stand speechless and look at each other—all this time the rest have been dancing)

sp.speaker: Miss E.
sp.p: What can it mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: It means that the rumours of ten years ago are proven. It was then suspected that the girl whom Mrs. Courtland brought every year from some unnamed place in the country, and introduced to everybody as her niece, was an impostor, which that foolish woman, in a freak of generosity, was thrusting upon society. The rumours died out for want of proof, and before Laura's beauty and dignity, but now they are confirmed, she is some beggar's child.

sp.speaker: Miss E.
sp.p: What do you think we ought to do? (Trafford surrenders Pearl to Demilt and comes down)

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Tell it—tell it everywhere, of course. The best blood of New York is insulted by the girl's presence. (Trafford coming down)

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: What have you three girls got your heads together for? Some conspiracy, I know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Go, girls, tell it everywhere.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.stage: (as the ladies distribute themselves about the groups)
sp.p: What is it all about? Your face is like a portrait of mystery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Look at this, and tell me what it means.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Where did you get this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: It is you who must answer, and society that will question. So Laura is not a Courtland?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You know, then—

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Everything! And will you marry this creature? You cannot, society will not permit your sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: This is not your business. Give me that letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Certainly, take it. But let me say one word—its contents are known. In an hour every tongue will question you about this secret, every eye will inquire.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I implore you! Do not breathe a word for her sake. (she turns scornfully away)

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: The secret's not mine.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Who knows it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Look! (points to others who are grouped about whispering and motioning towards Ray.)

div.stage: Enter Pearl L. U. E. and speaks to lady and gentlemen L. C.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: What will they do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Expose her! Expel her from society in which she is an intruder!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You dare not!

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O Ray, what is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: It means that society is a terrible avenger of insult. Have you ever heard of the Siberian wolves? When one of the pack falls through weakness the others devour him. It is not an elegant comparison, but there is something wolfish in society. Laura has mocked it with a pretence, and Society, which is made up of pretences, will bitterly resent the mockery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Very good! This handsome thief has stolen your breeding as well as your brains, I see.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: If you speak a word against her I will say that what you utter is a lie!

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: As you please, we will be silent. But you will find that the world speaks most forcibly when it utters no sound.

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: O, go and prevent her coming here.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: That I can do. (going up hastily sees Laura entering at C.) Too late. (he retreats R. C.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.p: Come girls! Let us look after our things. They are no longer safe when an accomplished thief enters. (music low, continues while all except Pearl and Ray pass out, eyeing Laura superciliously.)

div.stage: (Laura C., Pearl R.)

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Ray, Ray! why do you not come to her?

sp.speaker: Mrs. V.
sp.stage: (up C. of stage, surrounded by others)
sp.p: Are you not coming with us, Trafford?

sp.speaker: Pearl.
sp.p: Let us go home.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, stay with him! (pointing to Ray, who has held off) He shall not suffer the disgrace long. (about to faint, Ray runs forward, she proudly waves him away) It is Heaven's own blow!

div.head: SCENE FIRST.
div.stage: Interior of a basement. Street and railings seen through window at back. Entrance door L. C., stove with long pipe in fire-place, R. U. E. Table between two windows at back, with flowers, &c.,—humble furniture. Table C., three chairs. Closet, L. (2nd grooves.)
Peachblossom is discovered polishing stove, R.—(a slip-shod girl à la Fanchon.)

sp.l: A lordly knight and a lovely dame, were walking in the meadow,
But a jealous rival creeping came, a-watching in the shadow.
They heeded not, but he whet his knife and dogged them in the shadow;
The knight was brave, and the dame was true, the rival fared but badly;
For the knight he drew and ran him through, and left him groaning sadly.
The knight and dame soon wedded were, with bells a chiming gladly.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p:
The stove won't shine. It's the fault of the polish, I know. That boy that comes here, just fills the bottles with mud, and calls it stove polish. Only let me catch him. Ah! Ah! threatening gesture with brush I declare I'd give it up if I didn't want to make everything look smart, before Miss Nina comes in. Miss Nina is the only friend I ever had since I ran away from mother Judas. I wonder where old Judas is now? I know she's drunk, she always was; perhaps that's why she never tried to find out what became of me. If she did she could not take me away. Miss Nina begged me off a policeman. I belong to her. I wonder why she ain't got any other friends? She's awful mysterious. Tells me never to let any strangers see her. She's afraid of somebody, I know. It looks just as if she was hiding. I thought only bad girls, such as I, had to hide. If I was good and pretty like her, I wouldn't hide from the
President.

div.stage: still polishing.—Judas appears at window with basket of ornaments, &c.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Hum! Is your ma in, my dear?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Oh! aside Old Judas! She's found me out at last. No she hain't, or she'd have got me by the hair before she spoke, that's her way.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.stage: coming in at door. Peachblossom keeps her back towards her
sp.p: Any old clothes to change for chany, my dear? Where's your ma's old skirts and shawls, my pet? Get 'em quick, before mother comes in, and I'll give you a beautiful chany mug or a tea-pot for them. Come here, my ducky—see the pretty— recognises Peachblossom Eh! why you jail-bird, what are you doing here? Are you sneakin' it? Answer me, or I'll knock your head ag'in the wall. catches her by the hair.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: You just leave me be. I'm honest, I am. I'm good!

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: You're good? Where's my shoe? I'll take the goodness out of you.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Oh, oh! please don't beat me. I ain't good. I'm only trying to be.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: You're only trying to be, eh? Trying to be good, and here's me as was a weeping every night, thinking as you was sent up for six months. Who're you living with—you ain't a keeping house, are you?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: I'm living with Miss Nina.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Nina, what's she, concert saloon girl?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: No, she's a lady.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: A lady—and have such baggage as you about? Where's my shoe, I'll make you speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: I don't know what she is. She met me when the police were taking me up for loafin' down Hudson-street, and she begged me off.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Has she any money?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: No, she's poor.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Any nice clothes?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Oh, she's got good clothes.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Locked up, and she's got the key.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: You're lying, I see it in your eye. You're always shame-faced when you are telling the truth, and now you're as bold as brass. Where's my shoe? making a dash at her.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: There's Miss Nina. as if curtseying to some one behind Judas Good morning, miss.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Ah, my pretty dear! What a good lady to take you in and give you a home. turns and discovers the deception—in a rage You hussy. Peachblossom retreats Wait till I get you in my clutches again, and it won't be long. Miss Nina takes care of you, does she? Who will take care of her? Let her look to it. Laura enters d. f., plainly dressed, at back Beg pardon, Miss, I just called to see if you had any old clothes you'd like to exchange.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, I don't want anything, my good woman.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.stage: eyeing her sharply and going to door
sp.p: That's her—I'd know her anywheres!

div.stage: malicious glance, and exit door L. C.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: You've been very good this morning, Blossom. The room is as nice as I could wish.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Please 'm I tried because you are so good to me. Laura taking off her shawl and things Shall I sweep out the airy? Laura does not answer I guess I'd better—then she'll be alone, as she loves to be.

div.stage: takes broom and exit door, L. C.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.stage: opening a package and taking out photographs
sp.p: No pay yet for colouring 'till I have practiced a week longer. Then I shall have all the work I can do. They say at the photographer's I colour well, and the best pictures will be given me. The best! Already I have had beneath my brush so many faces that I know—friends of the old days. The silent eyes seem to wonder at me for bringing them to this strange and lowly home. picking up letters from table Letters, ah! answers to my advertisement for employment. No, only a circular “To the lady of this house.” What's that! starting Only Blossom sweeping. Every time there is a noise I dread the entrance of some one that knows me. But they could never find me in New York, I left them all so secretly and suddenly. None of them can expect I would have descended to this. But it is natural, everything will find its level. I sprang from poverty, and I return to it. Poor Pearl. How she must have wondered the next morning—Laura gone! But three months have passed, and they have forgotten me. Ray will cheer her. wrangling outside, Peachblossom bursts in, dragging Bermudas, with his professional tape, pins, blacking, and baskets, d. f.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Here he is m'm.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Leave go, I tell yer, or I'll make yer.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: He's the boy that sold me that stove polish what isn't stove polish.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: What is it then—s-a-a-y?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: It's mud! it's mud at tenpence a bottle.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Ah, where could I get mud? Ain't the streets clean? Mud's dearer than stove polish now.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: And your matches is wet, and your pins won't stick, and your shoe-strings is rotten, there now!

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Well, how am I to live? it ain't my fault, it's the taxes. Ain't I got to pay my income tax, and how am I to pay it if I gives you your money's worth? Sa-a-y?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Do let the boy alone, Blossom. Send him away.

div.stage: Enter Peanuts, at door, L. C.

sp.speaker: Peanuts.
sp.p: Extra! Hollo, Bermudas! how's your sister? Papers, Miss. Extra! Revolution in Mexico!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear, dear, this is the way I'm worried from morning till night.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Here, just you get out! This is my beat.

sp.speaker: Peanuts.
sp.p: Vell, I ain't blacking or hairpins now, I'm papers. How'm I hurting you?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Vell I'm papers at four o'clock, and this is my beat. Take care of me, I'm training for a fight. I'm a bruiser, I am.

sp.speaker: Peanuts.
sp.p: Hold yer jaw. they fight.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Get out with you, both of you! grand escapade, and exit of boys D. L. C.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Don't let's be troubled in this way again. Have you got the things for dinner?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Lor, no, miss. It's twelve o'clock, and I forgot. Peachblossom gets shawl, big bonnet from hooks on the wall, basket from closet, while Laura opens her pocket-book for money.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What did we have for dinner yesterday, Blossom?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Beefsteak 'm. Let's have some leg o' mutton to-day. We've never had that.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But I don't know how to cook it. Do you?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: No, but I'd just slap it on, and it's sure to come out right.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Slap it on what?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: The gridiron!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, we'd better not try a leg of mutton to-day. Get some lamb chops, we know how to manage them.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Taters, as usual, 'mum?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes; and stop Blossom—while you're buying the chops, just ask the butcher—off hand, you know—how he would cook a leg of mutton, if he were going to eat it himself—as if you wanted to know for yourself.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Yes 'm, but I'm sure it's just as good broiled as fried. exit d. L. C.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Now to be cook. laughing “The Tuesday Sociable” ought to see me now. Artist in the morning, cook at noon, artist in the afternoon.

div.stage: Snorkey raps at the door L. C., and enters.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Beg pardon, is there anybody here as answers to the name of A. B. C.?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: My advertisement for work.—Yes, give it to me.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: If I'd been taking something this morning, I'd say that I'd seen that face in a different sort of place from this.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Is there anything to pay? Why do you wait?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Nothing, Miss. It's all right. going—and aside But it ain't all right, Snorkey, old boy. goes out after looking at her, stops at window, and gazes in.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, an answer to my advertisement. reads To A. B. C:—“Your advertisement promises that you are a good linguist, and can teach children of any age. I have two daughters for whom I wish to engage your services while on a tour of Europe. Call at seven o'clock this evening, at No. 207, West., 34th Street Annersley.” Hope at last, a home, and in another land soon. I was sure the clouds would not always be black above me. kisses letter. Snorkey re-entering

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Miss, I say Miss? Laura starts Sh—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Only one word, and perhaps it may be of service to you. I'd do anything to serve you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And why me?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: I'm a blunt fellow, Miss, but I hope my way don't offend. Ain't you the lady that I brought a bouquet to on New Year's night—not here, but in a big house, all bright and rich, and who was so kind to a poor soldier?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Whoever you may be, promise to tell no one you saw me here.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: No fear, Miss. I promise.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sacredly?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: No need to do more than promise, Miss—I keeps my word. I promise Uncle Sam I'd stick to the flag—though they tore my arm off, and by darnation I stuck! I don't want to tell on you, Miss, I want to tell on some one else.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: They're looking for you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Byke. Laura utters a loud cry, and sinks on chair He's on it day and night. I've got his money in my pocket now, and you've got his letter in your hand this minute. Laura drops the letter in dismay.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Yes, it's his writin'—looks like a woman's, don't it? Lord! the snuff that man's up to, would make Barnum sneeze his head off. He's kept me in hand, 'cause he thinks I know you, having seen you that once. Every day he reads the advertisements, and picks out a dozen or so, and says to me—“Snorkey, that's like my little pet,” and then he sits down and answers them, and gets the advertisers to make appointments with him, which he keeps regularly, and regularly comes back cussing at his ill luck. See here, Miss, I've a bundle of answers to deliver as usual, to advertisers. I calls 'em Byke's Target Practice, and this time, you see, he's accidentally hit the mark.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: For heaven's sake do not betray me to him! I've got very little money, I earn it hardly, but take it, take it—and save me. offers money

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: No, miss, not a cent of it. Though Byke is a devil, and would kick me hard if he thought I would betray him.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I don't want you to suffer for my sake, take the money.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: No, I stood up to be shot at for thirteen dollars a month, and I can take my chances of a kickin' for nothing. But Byke ain't the only one, miss, there's another's looking for you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.stage: her look of joy changing to fear
sp.p: Another! Who?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p:
Mr. Trafford. Laura turns aside despairingly He's been at me every day for more than six weeks. “Snorkey,” says he, “do you remember that beautiful young lady you brought the bouquet to on New Year's night?” “Well,” says I, “Capt'n, the young lady I slightly disremember, but the
cakes and wine I got there that night I shall never forget.” “Search for that young lady,” says he, “and when you find her”—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, no, no; not even he must know. Do you hear—not he—not anyone. You have served them well; serve me and be silent.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Just as you please, miss, but I hate to serve you by putting your friends off the track—it don't seem natural—Byke I don't mind, but the capt'n wouldn't do you any harm. Just let me give him a bit of a hint. Laura makes an entreating gesture Well I'm mum, but as I've only got one hand, it's hard work to hold my tongue. going Not the least bit of a hint? Laura appealingly and then turns away They say when a woman says no she means yes. I wonder if I dare tell her that he's not far off. Perhaps I'd better not. But I can tell him. exit d. f.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: How shall I ever escape that dreadful man? And Ray searching for me too. Our friends, then, remember us, as well us our enemies.

div.stage: Enter Peachblossom, quickly d. f. shutting the door behind her, with basket, which she places on table, C.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: O, Miss Nina, whatever is into the people? There's a strange man coming down the entry, I heard him asking that red cap fellow about you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Byke! Fasten the door, quick. Peachblossom runs to door, it is slightly opened, she pushes it against some one on the other side

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: O, dear, he's powerful strong, I can't keep it shut. Go away, you willin': Oh! the door is forced and Ray Trafford enters

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, it is I!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ray! shrinks from him

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Dear Laura he stops as he becomes conscious that Peachblossom with her basket on her arm and her bonnet hanging on her back is staring at him I say, my girl, havn't you some particular business somewhere else to attend to?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: No, sir, I've swept the sidewalk and gone a marketing, and now I'm in doors and I mean to stay.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And wouldn't you oblige me by going for a sheet of paper and an envelope? Here's a dollar—try and see how slow you can be.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: You can't sheet of paper me, mister, I'm protecting Miss Nina, and I'm not to be enveloped.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Go as the gentleman asks you, Blossom.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Oh! takes money, fixes her bonnet First it's “Keep the man out,” now it's “Let him stay in alone with me.” But I suppose she's like all of us—it makes a great difference which man it is.

div.stage: exit d. f.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, when I approached you you shrank from me. Why did you do so?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Look around you and find your answer.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Pardon me, I did not come here to insult your misery. When I saw you I forgot everything else.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: And now it's time for us to remember everything. I told you to look around that you might understand that in such a place I am no longer Laura Courtland, nor anything I used to be. But I did not ask your pity. There is no misery here.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Alone, without means, exposed to every rudeness, unprotected, is this not misery for you?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Oh, it's not so bad as that.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, don't trifle with me. You cannot have exchanged everything that made you happy, for this squalid poverty, and not feel it deeply.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I have not time to feel anything deeply. takes basket up, goes to table, busies herself about preparing dinner I work from sunrise till night, and I sleep so soundly that I have not even dreams to recall the past. Just as you came in I was about to cook our dinner. Only think—lamb chops.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Lamb chops! It makes me shudder to hear you speak.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Does it? Then wait till I get the gridiron on the fire and you'll shiver. And if you want to be transfixed with horror stop and take dinner.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I will not hear you mock yourself thus, Laura. I tell you in this self-banishment you have acted thoughtlessly—you have done wrong.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Because, let the miserable creatures who slandered you say what they might, you had still a home and friends.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: A home! Where the very servants would whisper and point, friends who would be ashamed to acknowledge me. You are mistaken. That is neither home nor friendship.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: And you are resolved to surrender the past for ever.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: The past has forgotten me in spite of myself.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Look at me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Well, then, there's one who has has not forgotten me, but I desire that he may. You speak to me of bitterness. Your presence, your words, cause me the first pang I have felt since the night I fled unnoticed from my chamber, and began my life anew. Therefore I entreat you to leave me, to forget me.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Laura, by the tie that once bound us!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, once. It is a long time ago.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: What have I said? The tie which still—

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Mr. Trafford, must I remind you of that night when all arrayed themselves so pitilessly against me, when a gesture from you might have saved me, and you saw me without stretching a finger to the woman who had felt the beating of your heart. No, you made your choice then—the world without me. I make my choice now—the wide, wide, world without you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I have been bitterly punished, for we are never so humiliated as when we despise ourselves. But, by the heaven above us both, I love you, Laura—I have never ceased to love you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I thank you. I know how to construe the love which you deny in the face of society to offer me behind its back.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Will you drive me mad? I tell you, Laura, your misery, your solitude is as nothing to the anguish I have suffered. The maniac who in his mental darkness stabs to the heart the friend he loved, never felt in returning reason the remorse my error has earned me. Every day it says to me “You have been false to the heart that loved you, and you shall account for it to your conscience all your life. You shall find that the bitterest drops in the cup of sorrow are the tears of the woman you have forsaken.” And it is true. O, forgive me—have pity on me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I forgive you. Yes, and I pity you—and so good-bye for ever.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Of course I am nothing to you now, that is some comfort to me, I have only to be sorry on my own account, but I come to you on behalf of others.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Whom?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: My mother and Pearl, they ask for you. For them I have sought you, to urge you to return to them.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Dear little Pearl.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes, she has been quite ill.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: She has been ill?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Think of those two hearts which you have caused to suffer and do not drive me from you. It is not only wealth, luxury, and refinement which you have surrendered—you have also cast away those greater riches, loving and devoted friends. But they shall persuade you themselves—yes, I'll go and bring them to you, you cannot resist their entreaties.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: No, no, they must not come here, they must never know where I hide my shame, and you must never reveal it.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I promise it if you will go to them with me. Think, they will insist on coming unless you do.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Poor Pearl. If I go with you you promise not to detain me—to permit me to come back and to trouble me and my poor life no more?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I promise, but I know you will release me from it when you see them. I will get a carriage, so that no one will meet you. Wait for me, I shall not be long. It is agreed?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, it is agreed.

div.stage: Enter Peachblossom, d. f. with a sheet of paper foolscap and some enormous envelopes.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Here they are.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: That's a good girl, keep them till I come back. In half an hour, Laura, be ready.

div.stage: exit d. f.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: What's he going to do in half an hour?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: He's going to take me away with him for a little while, Peachblossom, and while I'm gone I wish you to be a good girl, and watch the house and take care of it till I return.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: I don't believe it, you won't return. crying That's what our Sal said when she went off with her young man, and she never came back at all. You shan't go; I hate him. He shan't take you away.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.stage: who is getting ready, putting her hat on, &c.
sp.p: Blossom!

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: I don't care, if you go away I'll go away; I'll bite and scratch him if he comes back. fiercely tearing up the paper and envelopes Let him come back—let him dare come back.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Blossom, you're very wicked. Go into the corner this minute and put your apron over your head.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: O, please, Miss Nina, let me go with you and I'll be so good and not say a word to any one. Do let me go with you. Let me ask him to let me go with you. figure passes the window Here he is, I see him coming.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Run, run, open the door. Peachblossom runs to door, throws it open, disclosing Byke—exclamation of horror from Laura

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Ah, my dear little runaway, found you at last, and just going out. How lucky! I wanted you to take a walk with me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Instantly leave this place!

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: How singular! You are always ordering me out and I am always coming in. We want a change. I will go out, and I request you to come with me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Blossom, go find an officer, tell him this wretch is insulting me.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Blossom? Ah—exactly! Here, you Judas.

div.stage: Judas enters L. C.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: O, miss, save me.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.stage: throws Peachblossom over to Judas, who drags her out L. C.
sp.p: Take care of that brat, and as for you, daughter, come with me.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Daughter.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Yes, it is time to declare myself. Paternal feeling has been too long smothered in my breast. Come to my arms, my child—my long-estranged child. takes out dirty handkerchief and presses his eyes with pretended feeling

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Heavens! is there no help? she attempts to escape, Byke seizes her.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: What an unfilial girl, you take advantage of a father's weakness and try to bolt. clutching her by the arm Come, go with me and cheer my old age. Ain't I good to take you back after all these years? drags her out L. C., she calling “help! help!”

div.head: SCENE SECOND.
div.stage: The Tombs Police Court. Long high desk with three seats across back, from R. to L., on platform. Railing in front, railing around L., with opening L. C. In front of railing, a bench R. and L.,—gate in C. of railing. Judge Bowling, and another Justice seated behind high desk C., with clerk on his L. Justice is reading paper, with his feet upon desk R. Policeman at R. and L. 1 2 E.

Policeman 999, at gate C. Hard-looking set of men and women on benches R. and L.,—Lawyer Splinter is talking to Rafferdi, an organ-man, who is in crowd down R. As the curtain rises, noisy buzz is heard.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Smithers, keep those people quiet. Policeman handling people roughly Here, easy—officer, treat those poor people decently. Well, whom have you got there?

sp.speaker: Police.
sp.stage: going to L. 1 E., and dragging urchin within railing
sp.p: Pickpocket, your honour. Caught in the act.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: What's he got to say for himself? Nothing, eh? What's his name?

sp.speaker: Police.
sp.stage: stooping down to boy as if asking him
sp.p: Says his name is Peter Rich.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: You stand a poor chance, Rich. Take him away! Bowling consults with another Justice, as the boy is taken off R.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.stage: to Rafferdi, who has his monkey and organ
sp.p: So you want to get out, eh? How much money have you got?

sp.speaker: Raff.
sp.p: Be jabers! half a dollar in cents is all the money I'm worth in the world.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: Give it to me. I thought you organ fellows were Italians.

sp.speaker: Raff.
sp.p: Divil doubt it! Ain't I got a monkey?

sp.speaker: Police.
sp.p: Here, you—come up here. takes Rafferdi inside the railing L.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Now then, what's this, officer?

sp.speaker: Police.
sp.p: Complaint of disturbing the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: What have you got to say for yourself?

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: If your honour please, I appear for this man.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, what have you got to say for him?

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: Here is an unfortunate man, your honour—a native of sunny Italy. He came to our free and happy country, and being a votary of music, he bought an organ and a monkey, and tried to earn his bread. But the myrmidons of the law were upon him, and the Eagle of Liberty drooped his pinions, as Rafferdi was hurried to his dungeon.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Rafferdi, you're an Irishman, ain't you? What do you mean by deceiving us?

sp.speaker: Raff.
sp.p: Sure I didn't. It's the lawyer chap there. I paid him fifty cints and he's lying out the worth of it.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: You fellows are regular nuisances. I've a great mind to commit you.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: Commit him? If the court please, reflect—commit him to prison? what will become of his monkey?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, I'll commit him too.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: You cannot. I defy the Court to find anything in the Statutes authorizing the commital of the monkey.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, we'll leave out the monkey.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: And if the Court please, what is the monkey to do in the wide world, with his natural protector in prison? I appeal to those kindlier feelings in your honour's breast, which must ever temper justice with mercy. This monkey is perhaps an orphan!

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Take them both away, and don't let me catch you here again, Mr. Rafferdi, or you'll go to jail.

div.stage: Splinter goes down,—Rafferdi exits L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Police.
sp.stage: pulling Sam, a nigger, who is drunk, out of a crowd
sp.p: Get up here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Look yah—don't pull me around.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Silence there! what's all this noise about?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Whar's do court? I want to see de Judge.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: My colored friend, can I assist you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Am you a Counseller-at-law?

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: Yes, retain me. How much money have you got?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I ain't got no money, but I've got a policy ticket. It's bound to draw a prize.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: Got any pawn tickets?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh course. giving him a handful

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, what's the charge?

sp.speaker: Police.
sp.p: Drunk and disorderly.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, my man, what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Dis here gemman represents me.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: We admit, if the Court please, that we were slightly intoxicated, but we claim the privilege, as the equal of the white man.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Very good. Commit him for ten days.

sp.speaker: Splint.
sp.p: But this is an outrage, your honour.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Take him off. motioning to Sam—Splinter sits down discomfited—Sam very wroth.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Take him away.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Look here, judge, hab you read the Civil Right Bill? You can't send dis nigger to prison, while dat bill am de law ob de land.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: That'll do, remove him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I ain't no gipsy, I'm one of de Bureau nigger, I am. Where am de law? Don't touch me, white man! Dis am corruption—dis am 'ficial delinquency! Policeman collars him and carries him off R. l E.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Any more prisoners? noise L. 1 E. What noise is that? Officer goes out. Byke enters L. 1 E., followed by the Officer who escorts Laura.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Where is the judge? Oh, where is the good, kind judge?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Well, my dear sir, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: O, sir, forgive my tears. I'm a broken-hearted man!

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Be calm, my dear sir. Officer, bring this gentleman a chair.

div.stage: Officer hands chair, R. C.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Ah, sir, you are very good to a poor distressed father, whose existence has been made a desert on account of his child.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Repress your emotion, and tell me what you want.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: I want my child.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: She is here, sir—here—my darling, my beautiful child, and so unfilial—so unnatural.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: How is this, young lady?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: It is all a lie. He is not my father.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Not your father? Oh, dear, oh, dear, you will break my heart!

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: This needs some explanation. If not his child, who are you?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I am—I dare not say it. I know not who I am, but I feel that he cannot be my father.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: O, dear—O!—

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Silence! to Laura, sternly You say you don't know who you are. Do you know this man?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Where and with whom do you live?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: I have lived alone for four months.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: And with whom did you live before that?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: O, forgive me, if I seem disobedient—but I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Then I must look to this gentleman for information.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p:
And I will gladly give it. Yes, sir, I will gladly tell. She was taken from me years ago, when she was but a little child, by rich people who wanted to adopt her. I
refused—they paid me—I was poor—I was starving—I forebore to claim her—she was happy, but they turned her forth four months ago into the street. I could not see her suffer—my child—the prop of my declining days. I begged her to come—she refused. My enemies had poisoned my daughter's mind against me, her father. I am still poor. I taught school, but I have saved a little money, only for her.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: How old is she?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Nineteen.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Your father is your legal guardian during your minority, and is entitled to your custody. Why are you so undutiful? Try to correct this?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Oh, bless you, dear good judge for these words.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: O, have I no friends, must I go with him?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Anything then. Exposure! Disgrace, rather than that!

div.stage: Judges consult.
Enter Snorkey, L.,

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Snorkey! the devil!

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Can I help you, miss? Only tell me what to do, and if it takes my other arm off, I'll save you.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you can help me! to Judge Will you let me send a message.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: You may do that.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Run to that house—not my house—but the one in which you saw me first. Do you remember it?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Don't I, and the wine and cakes.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Ask for Miss Pearl. Tell her where I am. Tell her to come instantly. Snorkey going Stay—tell her to bring the ebony box in mother's cabinet. Can you recollect?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Can I what? Gaze at this giant intellect and don't ask me! The ebony box—all right—I'm off.

div.stage: exit L.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: It would have been as well, young lady, to have answered frankly at first.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: O, sir! Don't be harsh with her! Don't be harsh with my poor child.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Your father has a most Christian disposition.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Sir, I have told you, and I now solemnly repeat it, that this man is no relation of mine. I desire to remain unknown, for I am most unfortunate; but the injustice you are about to commit forces me to reveal myself, though in doing so I shall increase a sorrow already hard to bear. Splinter talks with Laura aside.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: We sit here to do right, according to the facts before us. And let me tell you, young lady, that your obstinate silence has more than convinced us that your father's statement is correct. Further, unless the witnesses you have sent for can directly contradict him, we shall not alter our decision.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Let it be so. He says he gave me into the care of certain wealthy people when I was a little child.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: I am willing to swear to it.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Then he will be able to describe the clothes in which I was dressed at the time. They were safely kept. I have sent for them.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Let them be produced—and I will recognise every little precious garment. aside This is getting ferociously hot for me! Ha!

div.stage: Re-enter Snorkey with Ray hastily, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Here's a witness! Here's evidence! Policeman admonishes him.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.stage: Ray takes her hand through the rail
sp.p: Ray?

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I am a friend, sir, of this lady.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: He is a dreadful character—a villain who wants to lead my child astray! Don't—please don't let him contaminate her!

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Silence! to Ray Can you disprove that this young lady is his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: His daughter?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: He knows nothing.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Let him answer. Come—have you any knowledge of this matter?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I had been told, sir, that— Laura looks at him No—I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Have you brought the ebony box? It contained the clothes which I wore when—

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: I understand; but in my haste, and not knowing your peril I brought nothing. But can you not remember them yourself?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Write, then! handing her a memorandum book—to Bowling Sir, this lady will hand you a description of those articles which she wore when she was found thirteen years ago. Then let this scoundrel be questioned—and if he fail to answer, I will accuse him of an attempted abduction.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: That's the way.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: It will not be a great effort for me to remember.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Now, sir, I will listen to you. Ray and Laura are eager and expectant.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: A soiled gingham frock, patched and torn.

div.stage: Laura gives a shudder and turns aside.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: What kind of shoes and stockings?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Her foot were bare.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: And the colour of her hood?

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: Her dear little head was uncovered.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: He has answered correctly.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: It is useless to struggle more! Heaven alone can help me!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: You can see, sir, that this lady cannot be his daughter. Look at her and at him.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: I only see that he has pretty well proven his case. She must go with him, and let her learn to love him as a daughter should.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: She shall not! I will follow him wherever he goes.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.p: I appeal to the Court.

sp.speaker: Bow.
sp.p: Officer, take charge of that person, until this gentleman is gone.

sp.speaker: Byke.
sp.stage: coming forward with Laura who is dumb and despairing
sp.p: My child, try and remember the words of the good judge. “You must learn to love me as a daughter should.” leading her towards R.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Stay here, sir, I'll track him. No one suspects me! music—tablean—closed in by.

div.stage: Laura. R. Byke. R. C. Snorkey. L. C. Ray. L.

div.head: SCENE THIRD.
div.stage: Exterior of the Tombs, with ballads on strings upon the railings.
Enter Judas, followed by Peachblossom, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Only tell me where he has taken her, and I'll go with you—indeed I will.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: We don't want you, we wouldn't be bothered with you; she's our game.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: What are you going to do with her?

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Do! why we'll coin her. Turn her into dollars. We've had it on foot for a long time.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: What! Is she the rich young lady I heard you and Byke speak of so often before I got away from you?

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Heard me speak of! What did you hear?

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: O, I know! I know more than you suppose. When you used to lock me up in the back cellar for running away, you forgot that doors had key-holes.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: This girl must be silenced.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: What are you muttering about—don't you know how Byke used to throw you down and trample on you for muttering?

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: I'll have you yet, my beauty.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: I think you are a great fool, Judas.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Likely, likely.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Why don't you give up Miss Nina to that handsome young gentleman? He'd pay you well for the secret. He'd give his whole fortune for her, I know, I saw it in his face. And he'd treat you better than Byke does.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Not yet my chicken; besides, what does he care for her now? Isn't he going to marry the other girl—she's the one will pay when the time comes—but we intend to hold the goods 'till the price is high.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Then if you won't, I'll tell all as I knows. I'll tell him all I used to overhear about babies and cradles, and he'll understand it, perhaps, if I don't.

sp.speaker: Judas.
sp.p: Hang her—she'll make mischief. aloud Well, come along with me, my beauty, and I'll talk it over with you.

sp.speaker: Peach.
sp.p: Don't touch me, I won't trust you with your hands on me. Judas makes a dart at her I knew that was your game. But I'll be even with you yet. dancing off tantalizingly before Judas.—Both exit R.

div.stage: Enter Snorkey, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: I'm no more use than a gun without a trigger. I tried to follow Byke, but he smoked in a minute. Then I tried to make up with him, but he swore that I went against him in Court, and so he wouldn't have me at no price. Then I ran after the carriage that he got into with the lady, till a darn'd old woman caught me for upsetting her apple stand and bursting up her business. What am I to do now? I'm afraid to go back to the Cap'n, he won't have me at any price either, I suppose. gazing at ballads, hands in his pockets—going from one to the other.

div.stage: Enter Bermudas, L. 1 E., with ballads in his hands, and preparing to take others off the line, as if to shut up shop.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: What are you a-doing of—sa-a-y? Snorkey takes no notice This here's one of the fellows as steals the bread of the poor man. Reading all the songs for nothin', and got bags of gold at home. Sa-a-y!

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Well, youngster, what are you groaning about? Have you got the cholera?

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Ah! what are you doing? Taking the bloom off my songs? You've read them 'ere ballads till they're in rags.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: I was looking for the “Prairie Bird.”

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Perary Bird! eh? There ain't no perary bird. There's a “Perary Flower.”

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Now don't go into convulsion. I'll find it. turns to songs.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Sa-ay—you needn't look no further for that bird! I've found him and no mistake. He's a big Shanghae with a red comb and no feathers.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: He's dropped on me.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Ain't you a mean cuss, sa-ay? Why don't you come down with your two cents, and support trade?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: But I ain't got two cents. What's a fellow to do if he hasn't got a red?

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Hain't you? Where's your messages?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Havn't had one go to-day.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Where do you hang out?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Nowheres.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: My eye—no roost?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: I tell you what, come along with us—we've got a bully place—no rent—no taxes—no nothin'.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Down under the pier! I discovered it. I was in swimmin' and seed a hole and I went in. Lots of room, just the place for a quiet roost. We has jolly times every night I tell you on the dock; and when it is time to turn in we goes below, and has it as snug as a hotel; come down with us.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: I will! These young rascals will help me to track that scoundrel yet.

sp.speaker: Bermu.
sp.p: Now, help me to take in my show windows; it's time to shut up shop.

div.stage: Enter Ray Trafford, L.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: If what that crazy girl has told me can be true, Laura may yet be restored to her friends if not to me, for I have dispelled that dream for ever. But that villain must be traced immediately, or he will convey his victim far beyond our reach or rescue. Snorkey helping to take down songs, sees Trafford, who has crossed to R.

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: Hollo! Capt'n!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: The man of all I wanted. You tracked him?

sp.speaker: Snorkey.
sp.p: They was too much for me, sir—two horses was, but I saw them turn into Greenwich-street, near Jay.

sp.speaker: Ray.
